reviewText:
Spear of Destiny is one of the most challenging shooters I've ever had the pleasure (although sometimes the pleasure turned into despair and anger) of playing in my whole life.

It took me my sweet time, several years, to finish it. But I finally beat the whole episode today. 18 maps of pure awesomeness. The last map is one of the best maps ever to be a final map in any game. I couldn't believe what I was seeing when I saw it.

Now, this game is not for amateurs. If you beat the first Wolfenstein 3D game, and I mean all 6 episodes of it, in I'M DEATH INCARNATE, well, you're still gonna have quite the challenge when you play this one. Imagine the last map in episode 2, but 10x harder.

Any true Wolfenstein fan knows about this game, but if you've never heard of it and loved Return to Castle Wolfenstein, Wolfenstein 3D and are excited about The New Order, well, you should give this one a spin. Might be the little retro experience you were looking for. And, of course, it will keep you in your seat while you wait for The New Order to come out.
voteText: 74 of 77 people (96%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Spear of Destiny is another of id Software's amazing deliveries. A sequel to what is probably my favorite game of all time, Wolfenstein 3D.

The settings they chose for DOSBox don't appeal to me however. I am not keen on using filtered graphics. I like crisp pixels. If you would like to see what I mean there, is an easy way to set the graphics very crisp and original feeling, and while we are at it, we can also smooth out animation a lot:

1. Right-Click the game in Steam, and choose Properties".
2. Click on the "Local Files" tab.
3. Click "Browse Local Files".
4. Double click the "base" directory.
5. Open "SOD.conf" with notepad.
6. Look for the "[sdl]" section.
7. Change "output=ddraw" to "output=overlay".
8. Scroll down to "[cpu]" section.
9. Change "cycles=auto" to "cycles=12000".

Save and exit notepad.
Run the game and enjoy.

This smooths out animation greatly
date: and provides original crisp feeling graphics. Some people prefer the filtered look
hoursPlayed: just leave it as ddraw and only change the "cycles" option."

reviewText: Having beaten Wolf3d many times and with The New Order coming out, I figured I'd finally get around to playing The Spear of Destiny. Yes, this is a lot like Wolf3d but that's not really a bad thing. The levels seem a little more open and the bosses seem a little more difficult. Actually, the game in a whole is a lot more difficult than Wolf3d. And while it doesn't have MechaHitler (who happens to be one of my favorite video game bosses of all time) the end level is quite awesome both pre and post obtaining the spear. A must play for anyone who enjoyed Wolf3d.. I actually think I liked it more.

reviewText:
You could argue that this game is to Wolfenstein 3D what Doom 2 is to Ultimate Doom.
It is, but that's not saying much, since Wolfenstein 3D didn't offer much to add on to in the first place.
All the same problems are there, and the game is given a much shorter, higher intensity length with a better sense of context. It isn't especially bad, but, well, read my Wolfenstein 3D review to see my thoughts on this game.
All the same pros and cons are there.

reviewText:
A prequel to Wolfenstein 3D, Spear of Destiny tells its own story. Borrowing many of the mechanics from the first game, this feels very much like more of the same, which is not a bad thing at all.

If you play this, I strongly suggest following the below guide (all credit goes to OP):

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=588494544

Using ECWolf, it adds many modernisations to the game, such as being able to shoot with the mouse, which we take for granted in modern-day shooters.

Every bit as iconic as the original Wolfenstein 3D, this game deserves to be played. As a bonus, Missions 2 & 3 (Return to Danger and Ultimate Challenge) are included free of charge. While certainly not essential after the base game, they are a pleasant addition regardless.

Played on Windows 10 Pro x64 without any problems.

reviewText: This is basically an expansion for Wolfenstein 3D, but instead of it being divided into episodes it is one longer mission with bosses every few levels. It also has a really cool ending that reminded me of DOOM! Plus you get 2 mission packs for Spear of Destiny, but I didn't really like them. Some of the mission pack levels force you to find secrets to continue, have fun smashing your face in the wall. The mission packs do add different textures that make the game look and sound completely different, for better or worse. But the bosses in the mission packs are the same from the main game, and the ending is the same too, but it does actually have DOOM references. I did really enjoy playing the main missions, just not the mission packs. I would recommend Spear of Destiny to any Wolf3D fan.\n9/10\n(P.S. You have to press a button to move left and right by looking left and right, you can't look and move side to side at the same time, that is what made this game slightly challenging for me.)

reviewText:
A standalone of Wolfenstein which extends the story and gameplay of Wolfenstein 3D. The Spear of Destiny is said to be the lance of Versailles which was touched by Jesus, those who harness it are said to become immortal. The Wermarcht seek it out as B.J sets out to kill them before they steal it.

Gameplay
Your standard fare of Nazi-killin', secret spotting and meal gobbling franticness. Same as Wolfenstein 3D but with far more variety in map design and secret layouts also spots some of the most fanciest level design I have seen for a game of its age, Hallways are decroated with the skeletons of the dead, crumbling caverns with foliage and cathedrals with stained glass and portraitures of Hitler's ugly mug.

Gunplay
Handles the same as Wolfenstein 3D. You are locked to the X axis and cannot aim up or down (unless you use a different source port than the one given!) and you have to use your mouse keys or a mouse.

Graphics
Textures are more contrasting and pleasing to the eyes, patterns on walls don't look as bad (not as blocky as before). The immersion factor impresses me because of their creative use of 2D sprites giving the room a stylistic flare and the thematic style is consistent and believable.

Mechanics
The mechanics are very simple in Wolfenstein, you simply aim left or right aligning your shot to the enemy on screen and hit LMB (Left Mouse Button) to fire at him. Once he goes down he may drop ammo. Pressing Space on screen interacts with the environment and can unlock secrets. Progress through to the room with a switch 'Exit' to finish the level and to move on! Easy peazy.

Story
Stop Hitler and the Nazi's from gaining the powers held in the Holy Lance stolen from Versailles which will grant him UNLIMITED POWER!

Criticisms; Minor
Use of DOSBOX. Very limited features, Google ECWOLF and install it to have better sound and graphics!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein 3D: Spear Of Destiny			* 7/10
A prequel expansion for The first FPS by historical iD Software. During WWII, the american spy B. J. Blazkowitz is after the Spear of Destiny, stolen by the nazis. You have to run through 21 levels and various bosses. Simple as that. What else can I say? It's a damn old game, running on dosbox, so a little knowledge of old systems and dosbox might help to tune it a little to prevent annoying little details, but at least it's working fine.
I still DO NOT recommend to buy the game. Why? Because there's a free online version in the official wolfenstein site where you can play the first three episodes directly through your browser... And if you look deeper in a search engine you can find another site with all 6 episodes AND the spear of destiny expansion. It looks even more polished and plays smooth as silk, So why buying? -.-

+++PROs+++ GAMEPLAY. There's not much to say, as one of the first FPS it's quite simple to understand how it works. There are still hidden walls, secret levels and of course nazi soldiers with impossible coloured suits... XD
ADDED MISSIONS. Although I didn't advice to buy this edition on steam I have to point out that there are 2 added mission packs called Return to Danger" and "Ultimate Challenge". They can be a good reason to consider buying this release.---CONs--- DOSBOX. It's true
date: it's the only way to play it on modern PCs
recommended: but still as it is it's hard to play smooth. You have to know it a little to tweak the emulator performance to bring it to a good state of playability (CTRL+F11 or F12 to increase/decrease the CPU Cycle). For some odd reason seems like this is the only dosbox game I tried until now that crashes on launch for appearently no reason (Because it's the only one and happens only when I launch from steam
hoursPlayed: while if I launch directly the bat file inside the steamapps directory it works like a charm). Luckily it was enough to set compatibility on win XP SP3 for dosbox's exe.\nFREE. This game is almost 25 years old and still isn't in abandonware state but

reviewText:
Spear of Destiny is a mappack addon for Wolfenstein 3D. It adds 21 new levels to the original game and not much else.

The problem isn't that it's a bad addition to the game, especially back then when a mappack and an expansion were pretty much the same thing. The problem is that Wolf3D was already a game with a thriving modding and mapping community. You could already find tons of new maps, weapons and enemies, all free of charge, if you wanted more from your Wolf3D experience.

Today there is very little point in purchasing this. You can still get a ton of free mods and maps for Wolf3D if you so desire and there is very little reason to throw out more money than you already have.

reviewText: This is the ADD ON content to the old Wolfenstein 3D, so I give it the same review:  This game just about started it all for ID, the creators of DOOM.  Oddly enough it is still not too bad for a simple pass time, but long gone are the days you feel the joy and fun.  I spend hours searching Hitler pictures for secret rooms and saving ammo to waste a room full of Nazi's.  The amount of guns are limited,  the graphgics are now poor, and the enemy AI is lifeless.  However the sounds are still fun to hear and play.\n\nStill cool, but did not age as well as DOOM or Duke Nukem.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein 3D fans will enjoy Spear of Destiny.

Pros: Nostalgia
Cons: Graphics, Sounds, Controls, Gameplay

Players that love the very old-school play of Wolfenstein 3D will surely feel the same way about Spear of Destiny.  For most everyone else, however, the small improvements (e.g. more weapons, textures, and bosses) in Spear of Destiny cannot make up for its outdated graphics, sounds, controls and gameplay.  The simple AI and scarce design elements simply don't offer enough variety or interest.

7/10

reviewText:
Date: 2/10/16
Review Number: 14
Game: Wolfenstein: Spear of Destiny
From (Creator Publisher): id Software
Played On:Laptop
Steam Price as of Review: $4.99
Total Time played: 40 minutes
Review:

Ah, the classic Wolfenstein.  The games that can easily be called the grandfather of all first person shooters.  Within this game lies the seeds that have given us DOOM, DOOM 2, and every other FPS that followed (all of which were horrible).  Apparently the wheel of unintended consequences has decided that in homage to all of the games that followed in its wake, it was time to sit down and play a bit of where that all began (technically the sequel to that, though Wolfenstein 3D and Spear of Destiny were essentially the exact same game with slightly different map packs).  In the early 90s, consoles were well into their formative years, while PC gaming had just begun to crawl really, when a smaller software company known as id released a quasi-3d Nazi killing game that was essentially a bunch of flat textures in a structure that offered the illusion of 3D.  The game itself is fairly simple, playing a typical strong-man armed only with a knife and pistol, you sneak into a Nazi stronghold and proceed to do some significantly expensive interior redecorating, much to the chagrin of the current inhabitants,as they clearly did not expect  your arrival.  The gameplay is a barebones breakdown of everything current shooters are -- you walk around an environment looking for things to shoot, you shoot them before they shoot back, you find the way to the next area.  All in all, the game is surprisingly simple in comparison to games available today, the difference between the three guns primarily being the rate at which they spit out bullets, and the lack of auto aiming and realistic bullet physics means shooting a nazi in the elbow from half a post code away is as effective as a point blank center mass shot, but the game is still exceedingly fun.  the repetitive wall and floor textures hearken back to my childhood gaming years, and the sound of yelling nazis as they are shot never really gets old.  Though the game itself is comparatively short and simple in comparison to newer games, that's really okay, as this is better played in shorter stints, enjoyed as a brief trip down nostalgia lane.  Not entirely sure if it's worth five dollars of nostalgia, but it’s certainly worth something.

Game’s Fate: Its 13 megs, and a fun little time waster.  Kept
Buy/No Buy: I wouldn’t necessarily buy it at full price, but it goes on sale occasionally.  Definitely get it then.

reviewText: 22 years later, while the graphic are dated, game play is primative by todays standard, the game still remains fun. A sequel to wolfenstein 3d, with 2 expansions it added more maps and textures to the basic game. Graphic improvements were minimal, but the maps we mostly improved over its predecessor. This game was short lived, and doom quickly took the spotlight in 1993 as the must play fps. Other 3d perspective games were popping up, like ultima underworld and I ended up skipping this game back then. I am glad I finally went back and played through it in its entirety. For someone wanting basic and simple fun,  or to experience the evolution of 3d games first hand it is worth a play through.

reviewText:
Date: 2/10/16
Review Number: 14
Game: Wolfenstein: Spear of Destiny
From (Creator Publisher): id Software
Played On:Laptop
Steam Price as of Review: $4.99
Total Time played: 40 minutes
Review:

Ah, the classic Wolfenstein.  The games that can easily be called the grandfather of all first person shooters.  Within this game lies the seeds that have given us DOOM, DOOM 2, and every other FPS that followed (all of which were horrible).  Apparently the wheel of unintended consequences has decided that in homage to all of the games that followed in its wake, it was time to sit down and play a bit of where that all began (technically the sequel to that, though Wolfenstein 3D and Spear of Destiny were essentially the exact same game with slightly different map packs).  In the early 90s, consoles were well into their formative years, while PC gaming had just begun to crawl really, when a smaller software company known as id released a quasi-3d Nazi killing game that was essentially a bunch of flat textures in a structure that offered the illusion of 3D.  The game itself is fairly simple, playing a typical strong-man armed only with a knife and pistol, you sneak into a Nazi stronghold and proceed to do some significantly expensive interior redecorating, much to the chagrin of the current inhabitants,as they clearly did not expect  your arrival.  The gameplay is a barebones breakdown of everything current shooters are -- you walk around an environment looking for things to shoot, you shoot them before they shoot back, you find the way to the next area.  All in all, the game is surprisingly simple in comparison to games available today, the difference between the three guns primarily being the rate at which they spit out bullets, and the lack of auto aiming and realistic bullet physics means shooting a nazi in the elbow from half a post code away is as effective as a point blank center mass shot, but the game is still exceedingly fun.  the repetitive wall and floor textures hearken back to my childhood gaming years, and the sound of yelling nazis as they are shot never really gets old.  Though the game itself is comparatively short and simple in comparison to newer games, that's really okay, as this is better played in shorter stints, enjoyed as a brief trip down nostalgia lane.  Not entirely sure if it's worth five dollars of nostalgia, but it’s certainly worth something.

Game’s Fate: Its 13 megs, and a fun little time waster.  Kept
Buy/No Buy: I wouldn’t necessarily buy it at full price, but it goes on sale occasionally.  Definitely get it then.

recommended: no matter your reation time with a fast monitor/tv or a wired mouse/keyboard/controller. I would still recommend this game  for easier difficulties or if you enjoy classic games."
